nodes.bodyText: This is using uninitialized variables. Also total is unused outside of this disabled block of code.

The C language guarantees that static variables are initialized to zero.
I'll make that explicit and make all the statistical stuff conditional.
I think the option to disable the check should be mentioned in this message.
I thought of that, but I wasn't sure how obscure the bypass should be. If we're going to explicitly call it out, perhaps it should just be a normal command-line option?

I'm not sure how big the impact to service will be. If it turns out some customers are running jextract from a different JVM version, we should mitigate the impact by making it easy to find the workaround. I don't have strong feelings either way for sticking with the current option or making it a command line option.

It's both easier to talk about and use if it's a command-line option: how about -r (relax checking)?
I'll also document the remaining supported options.
Seems consistent with the other options in the help, -f and -v.

-interactive is no longer useful, it was replaced by DDR. We kept it alive after DDR was available to support the trprint subcommand, but trying to run that, it doesn't seem to work very well any more and I don't think anybody uses it. Bottom line, it shouldn't be included in the help, and I expect we could delete all the associated code.
Ok, I won't mention -interactive. I created #10764 to track removing the option and the support infrastructure.
I don't understand the purpose of this, perhaps a more detailed message is appropriate.

This is a commonly supported option with the meaning that subsequent arguments are not treated as options (even if they begin with -). A (perhaps unlikely) example:
jextract -r -- -v

considers the file named -v to be the core file.
I think it's a GNU convention; see the bash manual, for example.
